statement: G. Kuroni and Antihypetime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputKuroni isn't good at economics. processed.result: You are given a list of numbers representing the ages of people. Two people are friends if the bitwise AND of their ages is 0.  Find the maximum number of coins that can be earned by having people join a group and invite their friends, where each person gets coins equal to their age for each friend they invite.

There are $n$ people, each with a unique age represented by the integer $a_i$ ($1 \le n \le 2 \cdot 10^5$, $0 \le a_i \le 2 \cdot 10^5$). 

Two people are friends if and only if the bitwise AND of their ages is 0 ($a_i \text{ AND } a_j = 0$).

Initially, no one is a member of a group called "Antihype".  

Joining Antihype costs nothing.  If you are a member, you can invite a friend who is not a member, and you get $a_i$ coins for each friend you invite (where $a_i$ is your age).

What is the maximum number of coins all $n$ people can earn by joining Antihype and inviting each other?
